questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a content of the cubital fossa?
questions.explanation:
Medially

Lateral border of pronator teres

Laterally

Medial border of brachioradialis

Apex

Point of convergence of medial and lateral boundaries

Base

Imaginary line connecting the medial and lateral epicondyles of humerus.

Roof

Formed by deep fascia and reinforced by bicipital aponeurosis.The deep fascia is continuity of brachial and antebrachial fascia.

Floor

Lower portion of brachialis forms the floor of the upper part of the fossa; the supinator muscle forms the floor of the lower part of the fossa.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the median cubital vein is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: It connects the cephalic vein to the basilic vein.

options.label: B
options.text: It runs obliquely downward and laterally across the forearm.

options.label: C
options.text: It is superficial to the bicipital aponeurosis, which separates it from the brachial artery.

options.label: D
options.text: It is the primary choice for venipuncture and catheterization due to its stability.

questions.correct_answer: B. It runs obliquely downward and laterally across the forearm.

questions.text: A teenager presents with severe pain and swelling in the tip of her right index finger after slamming it into a door. Examination reveals significant swelling, erythema, tenderness, increased sensitivity, and difficulty moving the finger. An infection of the structure marked ‘X’ is diagnosed. What is most likely?

A 55-year-old male presents with intermittent pain and numbness in his right hand, especially after gripping. The physician suspects vascular insufficiency. Which test is the physician likely to perform to assess the blood supply to the hand?
Which of the following is not a content in the 4th compartment of extensor retinaculum?
questions.explanation:
Compartment of Extensor Retinaculum

Structure(s)

I
  • Abductor pollicis longus
  • Extensor pollicis brevis

II
  • Extensor carpi radialis longus
  • Extensor carpi radialis brevis

III
  • Extensor pollicis longus

IV
  • Extensor digitorum
  • Extensor indicis
  • Posterior interosseous nerve
  • Anterior interosseous artery

V
  • Extensor digiti minimi

VI
  • Extensor carpi ulnaris

questions.text: A newborn presents with weakness in the right arm after a difficult vaginal delivery. The arm is limp and hangs by the side, with the forearm pronated and the hand facing inward in a "waiter's tip" position. The infant has difficulty with shoulder abduction and elbow flexion. Which of the following nerve roots are most likely involved in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Structure

Description

Brachial Plexus

Formed by ventral rami of C5-T1 spinal nerves

Upper Trunk

Union of C5 and C6 ventral rami

Erb’s Point

Located in the posterior triangle of the neck, where the upper trunk divides into anterior and posterior divisions

Condition

Description

Horner's Syndrome

Involvement of T1 nerve root, indicating a more extensive injury

Skeletal Abnormalities

Bone deformities (e.g., glenoid dysplasia, clavicular shortening) due to muscle imbalance

questions.text: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the rotator cuff muscles?

options.label: A
options.text: The rotator cuff includes the Supraspinatus, Infraspinatus, Subscapularis, and Teres major, which collectively aid in shoulder abduction and external rotation.

options.label: B
options.text: The Subscapularis is the only rotator cuff muscle involved in internal rotation of the humerus.

options.label: C
options.text: The Infraspinatus and Teres minor are responsible for medial rotation of the shoulder joint.

options.label: D
options.text: The rotator cuff muscles are primarily located in the anterior aspect of the shoulder joint

questions.correct_answer: B. The Subscapularis is the only rotator cuff muscle involved in internal rotation of the humerus.
questions.explanation:
Muscle (Tendon)

Action

Nerve Supply

Supraspinatus

Initiates abduction of the shoulder

Suprascapular nerve(C5,C6)

Infraspinatus

External( lateral)rotation of the shoulder

Suprascapular nerve(C5,C6)

Teres minor

External(lateral) rotation of the shoulder

Axillary nerve (C5,C6)

Subscapularis

Internal (medial) rotation of the shoulder

Upper and lower subscapular nerves (C5,C6,C7)

questions.text: A surgeon is performing an axillary dissection for breast cancer and must be cautious not to damage structures piercing the clavipectoral fascia. Which of the following statements about these structures is TRUE?

options.label: A
options.text: The cephalic vein pierces the clavipectoral fascia and runs through the deltopectoral groove before draining into the axillary vein.

options.label: B
options.text: The thoracoacromial artery pierces the clavipectoral fascia and divides into pectoral, deltoid, acromial, and clavicular branches.

options.label: C
options.text: Lateral pectoral nerve passes through the clavipectoral fascia and innervates the pectoralis minor muscle after piercing the pectoralis major.

options.label: D
options.text: Lymphatic vessels draining the lateral breast region pierce the clavipectoral fascia and drain into the central axillary lymph nodes.

questions.correct_answer: A. The cephalic vein pierces the clavipectoral fascia and runs through the deltopectoral groove before draining into the axillary vein.
questions.explanation:
Feature Description
Location Lies deep to pectoralis major, extends from clavicle to axillary fascia
Pierced by Cephalic vein
Thoracoacromial artery and its branches
Lateral pectoral nerve
Lymphatics from lateral breast
Clinical relevance During axillary dissection, these structures must be protected

Feature Details
Cephalic vein (Option A) Arises from dorsal venous network of the hand
Runs in deltopectoral groove with deltoid branch of thoracoacromial artery
Pierces clavipectoral fascia to drain into axillary vein
Thoracoacromial artery (Option B) Branch of second part of axillary artery
Pierces clavipectoral fascia
Gives off pectoral, deltoid, clavicular, acromial branches (no 'axillary' branch)
Lateral pectoral nerve (Option C)  Arises from lateral cord of brachial plexus
Pierces clavipectoral fascia near thoracoacromial artery
Passes medial to pectoralis minor
Innervates pectoralis major only
Lymphatics (Option D) Drain lateral breast and pectoral region
Pierce clavipectoral fascia to reach apical axillary lymph nodes, not central nodes
Suspensory ligament of axilla Inferior extension of clavipectoral fascia
Anchors axillary fascia to maintain axillary fossa concavity

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with weakness in elbow flexion and loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of his forearm. Which of the following nerves is most likely involved in this patient’s condition?
questions.explanation:
Cord

Formation

Lateral Cord

Anterior divisions of upper and middle trunks

Posterior Cord

All three posterior divisions

Medial Cord

Anterior division of lower trunk (sometimes middle trunk)

Cord

Nerve

Motor Innervation

Sensory Innervation

Lateral Cord

Musculocutaneous (C5, C6, C7) (Option B)

Biceps brachii, brachialis, coracobrachialis

Lateral forearm

Lateral Root of Median (C5, C6, C7)

Contributes to median nerve (primarily hand muscles)

Contributes to sensory innervation of the hand

Posterior Cord

Axillary (C5, C6) (Option A ruled out)

Deltoid, teres minor

Lateral shoulder

Radial (C5, C6, C7, C8, T1) (Option C ruled out)

Triceps, brachioradialis, wrist and finger extensors, supinator

Posterior arm, forearm, dorsolateral hand

Upper Subscapular (C5, C6)

Subscapularis

None

Thoracodorsal (C6, C7, C8)

Latissimus dorsi

None

Lower Subscapular (C5, C6)

Subscapularis, teres major

None

Medial Cord

Ulnar (C8, T1) (Option D ruled out)

Flexor carpi ulnaris, flexor digitorum profundus (medial half), most intrinsic hand muscles

Medial hand, little finger, medial half of ring finger

Median (C5, C6, C7, C8, T1)

Pronators, wrist/finger flexors (except those supplied by ulnar), thenar muscles

Palmar hand (thumb, index, middle, lateral half of ring finger)

Medial Pectoral (C8, T1)

Pectoralis major, pectoralis minor

None

Medial Cutaneous Nerve of Arm (C8, T1)

None

Medial arm

Medial Cutaneous Nerve of Forearm (C8, T1)

None

Medial forearm

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with weakness in the upper limb following a fall on his shoulder. Physical examination reveals impaired movement in the extensor muscles of the arm. Injury to which part of the brachial plexus is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Trunk

Formation

Divisions

Upper Trunk

Union of C5 and C6 rami

Anterior: Flexor muscles (Option A ruled out)

Posterior: Extensor muscles

Middle Trunk


 

Continuation of C7

Anterior: Flexor muscles (Option B ruled out)

Posterior: Extensor muscles (Option C)

Lower Trunk

Union of C8 and T1 rami

Anterior: Flexor muscles (Option A ruled out)

Passing over first rib

Posterior: Extensor muscles

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman falls off her bicycle and lands on her outstretched hand. She presents with pain and swelling over the lateral aspect of her wrist. On examination, there is tenderness in the anatomical snuff box. Which underlying bone is most likely fractured?
Which of the following muscles is responsible for flexing the distal interphalangeal joints of the fingers?
questions.explanation:
Origin

Proximal three-quarters of the anterior and medial surfaces of the ulna and the interosseous membrane.

Insertion

Bases of the distal phalanges of the 2nd to 5th digits.

Action

Flexes the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints of the 2nd to 5th fingers and flexion of wrist.

Nerve Supply

Medial part by ulnar nerve and lateral part by median nerve (C8, T1)

Origin

Anterior surface of the radius and adjacent interosseous membrane.

Insertion

Base of the distal phalanx of the thumb.

Action

Flexion of phalanges of thumb

Nerve Supply

Median nerve (anterior interosseous branch) (C8, T1).

Origin
  • Distal one-quarter of the anterior surface of the ulna.

Insertion
  • Distal one-quarter of the anterior surface of the radius.

Action
  • Pronation of the forearm (pulls the radius over the ulna).

Nerve Supply
  • Median nerve (anterior interosseous branch) (C8, T1).

questions.text: Match the wall of the axilla with the structure forming it: Wall Structure forming a. Anterior wall 1. Serratus anterior b. Posterior wall 2. Bicipital groove c. Medial wall 3. Clavipectoral fascia d. Lateral wall 4. Subscapularis
questions.explanation:
Wall of axilla

Contributing structure

Anterior Wall
  • Pectoralis major
  • Clavipectoral fascia
  • Pectoralis minor

Posterior Wall
  • Subscapularis
  • Teres major
  • Latissimus dorsi

Medial Wall
  • Upper four ribs with intercostal muscles
  • Upper part of serratus anterior

Lateral Wall
  • Bicipital groove of humerus
  • Coracobrachialis
  • Short head of biceps brachii

questions.text: All are true about the shown muscle except.

options.label: B
options.text: Causes flexion of arm at shoulder joint

questions.explanation:
Muscle

Attachments

Nerve supply

Action

Biceps brachii
  • Origin: Short head- Coracoid process ; Long head- Supragelnoid tubercle
  • Insertion: Radial tuberosity

Musculocutaneous nerve (C5-C6)

Flexion and supination of forearm

Brachialis
  • Origin: anterior humerus
  • Insertion: coronoid process & ulnar tuberosity
  • Motor: Musculocutaneous nerve
  • Proprioceptive: Radial nerve

Flexion of forearm

Coraco- brachialis
  • Origin: medial coracoid process (Option D)
  • Insertion: medial aspect of middle humerus

Musculocutaneous nerve (C5-C7) (Option A)

Flexion of arm (Option B)

questions.text: Patient following RTA was brought to ED, where he was told that his ulnar nerve is injured. Which of the following muscles would be affected in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Muscle

Attachments

Nerve supply

Action

Abductor pollicis brevis (Option C)
  • Origin: Scaphoid tubercle, crest of Trapezium and flexor retinaculum
  • Insertion: Base of proximal phalanx of thumb

Median nerve

Abduction of thumb

Flexor pollicis brevis (Option B)
  • Origin: Capitate, crest of Trapezium and flexor retinaculum
  • Insertion: Base of proximal phalanx of thumb

Median nerve

Flexion of metacarpo-phalangeal joint of thumb

Opponens pollicis (Option D)
  • Origin: crest of Trapezium and flexor retinaculum
  • Insertion: Lateral half of palmar surface of the shaft of thumb metacarpal

Median nerve

Opposition of thumb towards fingers

Adductor pollicis (Option A)
  • Origin: Oblique head- base of 2nd-3rd metacarpal ; transverse head- shaft of 3rd metacarpal
  • Insertion: Base of proximal phalanx of thumb (medial aspect)

Ulnar nerve

Adduction of thumb

questions.text: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the muscles involved in abduction of shoulder?

options.label: A
options.text: Supraspinatous is involved in initiation of abduction.

options.label: B
options.text: Deltoid is responsible for 0-15 degree abduction.

options.label: C
options.text: Supraspinatous is responsible for 15-90 degree abduction.

options.label: D
options.text: Infraspinatous is responsible for 0-15 degree abduction.

questions.correct_answer: A. Supraspinatous is involved in initiation of abduction.
questions.explanation:
Shoulder abduction
  • Supraspinatus (0-15)
  • Deltoid (15-90)
  • Serratus anterior (90°-180°)
  • Upper and lower fibers of trapezius (90°-180°)

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the attachments on the coracoid process?

options.label: A
options.text: The short head of biceps brachii and coracobrachialis insert onto its medial border.

options.label: B
options.text: The conoid ligament attaches to the tip of the coracoid process.

options.label: C
options.text: The pectoralis minor muscle inserts onto the medial border of the upper surface.

options.label: D
options.text: The coracoacromial ligament attaches to the superior ridge of the coracoid process.

questions.correct_answer: C. The pectoralis minor muscle inserts onto the medial border of the upper surface.

questions.text: Identify the correctly marked attachments of the Upper end of the Humerus.

options.label: A
options.text: A- Supraspinatus; B- Infraspinatus; D- Pectoralis major

options.label: B
options.text: A- Teres minor; B- Infraspinatus; D- Subscapularis

options.label: C
options.text: C- Pectoralis major; D- Supraspinatus; E- Subscapularis

options.label: D
options.text: B- Infraspinatus; C- Pectoralis major; D- Supraspinatus

questions.correct_answer: A. A- Supraspinatus; B- Infraspinatus; D- Pectoralis major

questions.text: Which of the following is the root value of the nerve that provides sensory innervation in the area marked (X)?
questions.explanation:
Sensory Supply of Arm

Region

Nerve

Derivative of

Root values

Upper medial part

Intercostobrachial

2nd intercostal

T2

Lower medial part

Medial cutaneous nerve of arm

Medial cord of brachial plexus

T1, T2

Upper lateral part

Upper lateral cutaneous nerve of arm

Axillary nerve

C5, C6

Lower lateral part

Lower lateral cutaneous nerve of arm

Radial nerve

C5, C6

Posterior region

Posterior cutaneous nerve of arm

Radial nerve

C5

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient presents to the ED with a tension pneumothorax. The physician decides to perform a chest drain insertion to relieve the pressure. As the physician prepares for the procedure, they review the anatomical landmarks to ensure they insert the drain safely. Which muscle defines the posterior boundary of the Triangle of Safety, ensuring that the physician avoids vital structures during the chest drain insertion?
questions.explanation:
Anteriorly

Lateral border of the pectoralis major muscle.

Posteriorly

Lateral border of the latissimus dorsi muscle.

Inferiorly

A horizontal line at the level of the 5th intercostal space (usually aligned with the nipple in males).

Superiorly

Base of the axilla(armpit).
